results.title: Amiel Courtin-Wilson compilation
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Tag
results.brief_description: This proposed public imaging project shows a middle-aged woman standing in the middle of a well-furnished lounge room, wearing only her underwear and a blindfold. Other middle-aged people stand around her, also in their underwear, as she tries to find them while blindfolded. Bumping into things, tripping over furniture and laughing in the process- we follow the game from room to room as the woman in the blindfold tries to catch the various people taunting her. Finally tagging a younger man in the kitchen, the woman rips off the blindfold to see who she has caught. The image then cuts to static briefly and we start the game again, only this time with the man that was found or “tagged” now wearing the blindfold. This process repeats a number of times until most people at the party have been blindfolded. Stylistically, the video material will be a mixture of handheld home video cinematography juxtaposed with locked-off tripod material shot with multiple video cameras. The video imagery will then be degraded and transferred to 16mm- the final, highly textured imagery resembling a badly tuned television broadcast of surveillance camera footage.

results.title: The Effects of fire
results.brief_description: This proposed public imaging piece shows a series of close up portraits of domestic objects being burnt to abstraction, creating an inventory of domestic combustion in this piece. Punctuated with subtle yet deliberate, almost mechanised camera moves and cut in a very subdued fashion, this piece will be predominantly shot with a macro lens and will also be given a highly colour saturated visual treatment in post production.

results.title: Andy Hardy's private secretary
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Andy Hardy Series”.
Mickey Rooney is lovable as the evervescent teenager Andy with the stern judge father and understanding mother. Andy is about to graduate from high school and gets an inflated opinion of himself. He hires a social secretary played by Kathryn Grayson to sort out his complicated domestic affairs. Grayson does a superb rendition of Strauss’ “Voices of Spring.”

results.title: Love finds Andy Hardy
results.creator_credit: George B. Seitz, Loews Incorporated and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Andy Hardy Series”.
The fourth film in the series and the first to put Andy’s name in the title. The story moves at a jitterbug pace along comic and heartfelt storylines. Andy (Mickey Rooney) is in a fix as he has made dates for the Christmas dance with steady girlfriend Polly (Anne Rutherford) and voluptuous Cynthia (Lana Turner). Meanwhile Dad (Lewis Stone) must oversee the household while Mum (Fay Holden) is caring for Grandma. The new kid next door (Judy Garland in the first of three fondly remembered Andy Hardy appearances) helps Andy out of his jam and how she does it is an absolute delight, as are her renditions of “It never rains but what it pours”, “In-Between” and “Meet the beat of my heart.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: George B. Seitz, Loews Incorporated and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer

results.title: Republic of virtue
results.creator_credit: James Kent, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “American visions”.
In this first program of the series, Robert Hughes announces his intention to look at America through the lens of its visual culture and to see what we can tell about the American experience through the things Americans have made. The program charts the foundation of American identity following the War of Independence and ends on the eve of the American Civil War. The dominance of neo-classicism as a style which would imbue the nation with age-old values came to rule the aesthetics behind the building of Washington, D. C. America’s first major architect, Thomas Jefferson, is profiled with sequences at his home in Monticello and The University of Virginia, both of which he designed. The capital’s monuments to George Washington and Lincoln echo the need for authority, carried through in minimalist form today by the Vietnam Memorial designed by Maya Lin. The work of the nation’s first major painters; Benjamin West, John Singleton Copley, and Charles Willson Peale is outlined and the paintings in the Capitol Building are described. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: The Promised land
results.creator_credit: Christopher Spencer, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “American visions”.
In the second program of the series, Robert Hughes explores how religion was to have a fundamental impact on the shaping of American culture. The first European settlers presented the New World as both paradise and hell, a source of plunder, and a center of religious fantasy. During the early years of what Hughes describes as an invasion of North America by Europeans, the Spaniards conquered New Mexican Indian pueblos and citadels such as Acoma and set up their own architectural forms. These came to include the adobe Catholic church and the art of the santos- crude and vivid and designed to drive out the ancient gods from Indian minds. Meanwhile, seventeenth-century New England began to create a severe culture of practicality and moral rigor produced by Puritanism and later Utopian sects such as the Shakers. Then the Germans came, the Pennsylvania Dutch, the Quakers. In an America conceived as a religious refuge, a sanctuary for what Abraham Lincoln called the “half-chosen people,” what was used bears the print of what was believed. This pervaded the early paintings, crafts and buildings of Puritan America. The program concludes with the emergence of a culture which could begin to be called American. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Andy Hardy meets debutante
results.creator_credit: George B. Seitz, Loews Incorporated and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Andy Hardy Series”.
Andy (Mickey Rooney) is dazzled by a picture in a magazine of a glamorous debutante (Diana Lewis). When Judge Hardy’s (Lewis Stone) crusade to save an orphanage takes him to New York City, Andy joins him in the hope of meeting his dream girl. However, the Big Apple shows little sympathy for a cocky, small town boy and his hairbrained schemes to break into high society backfire with disastrous but humerous results. Finally, his old pal Betsy Booth (Judy Garland), a high society girl herself, lends Andy a hand - and a tuxedo. This is one of the most entertaining films in the series and features Judy Garland performing “Alone” and “I’m Nobody’s Baby.”

results.title: American visions
results.brief_description: Written and presented by Robert Hughes, this 8 part series traces the development of America by following its art and architecture from Spanish settlement to the present day. A companian website to the series can be found at: http://www.pbs.org/wnet/americanvisions/menu.html

results.title: Age of anxiety
results.creator_credit: John Bush, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “American visions”.
The subject of Hughes’ final program is American art of the late twentieth century. The United States entered the 1960’s as a rich and powerful nation, confident in its virtuous destiny, but by the end of the decade the dreams were shattered. The terrible conflict of Vietnam divided the country as it had not been divided since the Civil War a century earlier. America’s “Age of Anxiety” had begun. Hughes looks at the “tableaux” of Ed and Nancy Reddin Kienholz, works that range across the whole canon of American public imagery. He tells the story of the klutzy images of blood-stained Ku Klux Klansmen in the paintings of Philip Guston. He also meets many of the artists; Eric Fischl, Bruce Nauman and Louise Bourgeois, whose work reflects the uncertain society of the late sixties and early seventies. Hughes argues that it was Ronald Reagan’s economic policies that created the art-market boom of the 1980’s, with inflated prices and inflated egos. He confronts one of the darlings of the decade, former bond dealer Jeff Koons, in the hope of finding something meaningful in a large sculpture of a crucified kitten in a sock. For Hughes, the eighties were “a low, dishonest time for much American art.” Written and presented by Robert Hughes.
